'Dragon' is a partially reusable spacecraft developed by SpaceX, an American
private space transportation company based in Hawthorne, California. Dragon is
launched into space by the SpaceX Falcon 9 two-stage-to-orbit launch vehicle,
and is capable of both manned and robotic operation.

During its uncrewed maiden flight in December 2010, Dragon became the first
commercially built and operated spacecraft to be recovered successfully from
orbit. On 25 May 2012, an uncrewed variant of
Dragon became the first commercial spacecraft to successfully rendezvous with
and be attached to the International Space Station (ISS). SpaceX is contracted
to deliver cargo to the ISS under NASA's Commercial Resupply Services program,
and Dragon began regular cargo flights in October 2012.

SpaceX is additionally developing a crewed variant of the Dragon called
DragonRider. DragonRider will be able to carry up to seven astronauts, or some
combination of crew and cargo, to and from low Earth orbit. SpaceX has received
several U.S. Government contracts to develop its crewed variant, including a
Commercial Crew Development 2 (CCDev 2)-funded Space Act Agreement in April
2011, and a Commercial Crew integrated Capability (CCiCap)-funded space act
agreement in August 2012. The spacecraft's heat shield is furthermore designed
to withstand Earth re-entry velocities from potential Lunar and Martian
categories: Supply vehicles for the International Space Station
